isis.stitle: TSI 91-16-06 - Procedure To Correct Difficult-To-Open Door Latches

subjectgroup.subject: Procedure To Correct Difficult-To-Open Door Latches

geninfo.para: Premium model door latches that are difficult to open can be corrected through one of the three following procedures:

note.para: Do not use WD-40 or other water-displacing aerosols. You must use a lithium or moly-based grease or lube.

item.para: Properly lubricate existing latch and lock parts, using approved lubricant and method (see LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHES section).
Lubricate the latch and lock parts as outlined in LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHES section, and install new adjustable inside and outside door handle rods.

Lubricate the latch and/or lock parts as outlined in LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHESsection. Install new adjustable inside and outside door handle rods. If latch is worn, replace with same part number.

note.para: Lubrication of the latch will greatly reduce the effort required to open the latch. As a result, if the latch is still difficult to operate, the door is probably locked. If the operator continues to attempt to open the door, when locked, the adjustable rods may bend. These rods require 125 lbs. of force to permanently bend the ends of the rods. A force greater than 100 lbs. will flex the end of the rod and may cause the spring clip to pop loose.
Lengths are measured on centerline of rod ends, in a straight line from one end to the other ( Figure 1).

svcproc.title: LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHES
svcproc.para: To overcome difficulty in operating door latches, the outer portion of the latch mechanism should be lubricated with a lithium or moly-type lubricant as illustrated in Figure 2. DO NOT USE WD-40 OR OTHER WATER-DISPLACING AEROSOLS WHICH REMOVE THE LUBRICANT.
Lithium or moly-type lubrication can be purchased in an aerosol-type spray can. This is very easy to apply and is very effective.
Lubricant should be sprayed generously onto the jaw, jaw pivot, lever pivot and spring areas of the outer portion of the latch.
Chassis lube may also be applied, using a bearing grease needle through center of paws.
While the inside door panel is off, lubricate moving contact points on lock mechanism inside door.

svcproc.title: PROCEDURE TO INSTALL NEW ADJUSTABLE RODS

svcprocinfo.para: For more detailed information on cab door repair refer to GROUP 16, 96/9700 CAB and 93/9400 CAB Sections in the Service Manual.

step1.para: Roll window all the way up and remove the inner door panels.

Remove the old rods for the inside and outside door handles. Inspect the rod end clips for damage; replace as necessary. Lubricate the door latch as outlined in LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHES with lithium or moly-lube/grease.
Check each new rod length and set to nominal dimensions as required (see Parts Information Table 1).
Install the new handle rods (with turnbuckle as shown in Figure 3). Re-install the upper door panel using one screw on each end of panel.

Check to insure the door latch is in the unlocked position before adjusting the rod. Close the paws of the latch (in the latched position). Operate the door handle and observe latch operation. The latch should operate before the handle reaches the end of its travel and with clearance as shown in Figure 4. Close the paws before each trial.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. WHEN LATCH IS OPENED WITH DOOR HANDLE (INSIDE OR OUTSIDE), THE VERTICAL CLEARANCE SHOULD BE APPROXIMATELY 1/16 INCH

step1.para: Adjust the outside door handle rod first. Adjust the rod length as necessary by rotating the turnbuckle to obtain clearance in Figure 4. Close the latch paws and recheck for proper operation by opening handle.
Shortening the rod will decrease travel required to open latch.

note.para: If rod is adjusted too short, the latch will not close, or will be very sensitive to additional adjustment.

step1.para: After the outside handle rod is adjusted, operate the inside door handle, and adjust the rod in the same manner. It should also release the latch just prior to the end of the handle movement. Close the paws and recheck for proper operation by opening the inside handle.
When the adjustment is complete, tighten the jam nuts on each end at the turnbuckle.
Roll window up and down to check that it does not interfere with the door handle rods.
Re-assemble inner door panel and recheck latch operation of inside and outside handles, lock button and keylock features. Be sure all operate properly.

Lower window glass to bottom of door and remove inner door panels, following instructions in the Service Manual. Remove the glass fastener screws and window guide. Separate window guide from lever. Push glass up to top of window frame and prop or tape in place.

note.para: Do not allow the upper door panel to hang on the inside handle rods; this will damage the plastic rod end clips.

step1.para: Remove the old rods for the inner and outer door handles and lock button. Inspect the rod end clips for damage and replace as necessary. Lubricate the door latch as outlined in the LUBRICATION OF CAB DOOR LATCHES section with Lithium or moly-lube/grease.

Inspect the outdoor handle assembly. If extension arm is loose, or if it has a cold-headed rivet as shown in Figure 5, remove it. Enlarge the hole and install a 1/4 inch bolt and locknut. If a Huck bolt ( Figure 5) was used in the assembly, do not replace it.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. IF RIVETED, REMOVE AND REPLACE WITH BOLT PER INSTRUCTIONS. DO NOT REPLACE UNLESS DEFECTIVE

step1.para: Check each new rod length and set to nominal dimensions as listed in Table 1, Parts Information.
Install the new outside handle rod (with turnbuckle as shown in Figure 6).

Check to insure the door latch is in the unlocked position before adjusting the rod. Close the paws of the latch (in the latched position). Operate the door handle and observe latch operation. The latch should open before the handle reaches the end of its travel and with clearance as shown in Figure 4. Close the paws before each trial.

Adjust the outside door handle rod first. Adjust the rod length as necessary by rotating the turnbuckle to obtain clearance in Figure 4. Close the latch paws and recheck for proper operation by opening handle. Tighten the jam nuts at the turnbuckle.
Shortening the rod will decrease travel required to open latch.

note.para: If rod is too short, latch will not close or will be very sensitive to additional adjustment.

step1.para: After the outside handle rod is adjusted, install the inside door handle rod (with turnbuckle as shown in Figure 6), and re-install the upper door panel with two (2) screws at the front (hinge) edge of the door.

note.para: This will allow the other end of the panel to be pulled out to see the turnbuckle after adjustment.

step1.para: Take care to position the panel in the correct location. Hold it against the door frame while adjusting the rod length as this will affect the handle rod adjustment. If a prop was used to support the window, check to be sure it is not touching the rod; this will affect rod adjustment.
Operate the inside handle and observe latch operation. The latch should open before the handle reaches the end of its travel as shown in Figure 7.
CAREFULLY reach up behind the panel and adjust the rod length as necessary by rotating the turnbuckle. Close the latch paws and recheck for proper operation by opening the inside handle.

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. THE DOOR LATCH SHOULD OPERATE WHEN THE INSIDE HANDLE IS APPROXIMATELY 1/8 INCH BEFORE END OF TRAVEL

step1.para: Tighten the jam nuts at the turnbuckle. Complete the installation of the top trim panel screws. Recheck latch operation of inside and outside handles, lock button and keylock.
Re-assemble lock button rod and re-install window glass in guide. Roll window up and down to check that window mechanism does not contact handle rods.
Re-assemble inner door panels and recheck latch function.
